Certainly! Here are a few examples of cities that have successfully implemented bike-sharing programs and seen positive results:

1. Paris, France:
Paris launched the world's first large-scale bike-sharing program, Velib, in 2007. Today, it boasts 14,500 bikes across the city and over 30 million trips a year. According to a study by the French government, the program has reduced CO2 emissions by nearly 1,000 tons per year and has eliminated 12,800 private car trips per day.

2. Copenhagen, Denmark:
Copenhagen's bike-sharing program, Bycyklen, launched in 2014, offers electric bikes equipped with touchscreens and GPS technology. Since its launch, the program has seen over 2 million rentals, and 13% of daily trips in the city are now made by bike. The program has helped reduce traffic congestion and CO2 emissions in the city.

3. Beijing, China:
Beijing launched its bike-sharing program in 2015, and it has since grown to become one of the largest in the world. With over 2.4 million bicycles, the program has reduced traffic by over 1 million cars per day, saving 1.25 million tons of CO2 emissions per year.

4. Washington D.C., USA:
Washington D.C.'s Capital Bikeshare program launched in 2010 and now boasts over 4,000 bicycles and 500 stations. According to a survey by the National Association of City Transportation Officials, bike-sharing programs like Capital Bikeshare can reduce car trips by up to 4%.

These are just a few examples of cities that have successfully implemented bike-sharing programs, but there are many more around the world that have seen similar positive results.
